Review A review on fundamentals for designing stable ruthenium-based catalysts for the hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions Wangyan Gou a b Yichen Wang a b Mingkai Zhang c Xiaohe Tan b Yuanyuan Ma a b * Yongquan Qu b * a Research & Development Institute of Northwestern Polytechnical University in Shenzhen, Shenzhen 518057, Guangdong, China Research & Development Institute of Northwestern Polytechnical University in Shenzhen Shenzhen Guangdong 518057 China Research & Development Institute of Northwestern Polytechnical University in Shenzhen, Shenzhen 518057, Guangdong, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi'an 710072, Shaanxi, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Northwestern Polytechnical University Xi'an Shaanxi 710072 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi'an 710072, Shaanxi, China c School of Science, Xi'an University of Technology, Xi'an 710048, Shaanxi, China School of Science Xi'an University of Technology Xi'an Shaanxi 710048 China School of Science, Xi'an University of Technology, Xi'an 710048, Shaanxi, China * Corresponding author Clean and renewable energy is generally localized and intermittent. Thus, energy conversion and storage technologies are necessary to compensate for these shortcomings. Electrolytic water splitting presents a reliable and promising energy technology for producing high purity hydrogen (H2). Among the platinum metals, ruthenium (Ru) has gained significant attentions as it generally outperforms commercial catalysts in terms of activity at a more affordable price. Although great progress has been made in improving the catalytic activity of Ru-based catalysts, stability remains a major challenge hindering their practical applications. To this end, this review introduces the fundamentals of the stability over Ru-based catalysts for water splitting, including the reaction mechanisms of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), measurement methods and evaluation criteria, as well as deactivation mechanisms. Moreover, the up-to-date advances of representative strategies for improving HER and OER stability of Ru-based catalysts are further discussed with respect to specific design principles and underlying mechanisms. Ultimately, insights into the challenges and opportunities for Ru-based electrocatalysts are provided to promote the development of next-generation Ru-based catalysts with exceptional stability. This review aims at guiding the design and synthesis of superior catalysts, generating increased interest among researchers, and stimulating further advanced research. Graphical Abstract The fundamentals on stability of ruthenium-based catalysts, strategies and recent advances to design stable ruthenium-based catalysts for the hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution reactions are summarized in this review. Keywords Electrocatalysis Water splitting Deactivation mechanism Ruthenium-based catalyst Stability 1 Introduction In recent decades, the excessive reliance on fossil energy has led to serious environmental issues and energy crisis. In this regard, there is a growing interest in exploring affordable and long-lasting renewable energy alternatives [1–3]. However, these clean and renewable energy sources are localized and intermittent, making it challenging to meet the actual demand. Therefore, energy conversion and storage technologies are needed to overcome these limitations [4–6]. High-purity hydrogen (H2), which can be produced by photoelectrochemical and electrochemical water-splitting, presents great potential as an abundant, accessible, economical, and environmentally friendly source of energy with zero carbonaceous species emission among various energy alternatives (Fig. 1 ). Water electrolysis proves to be an attractive, promising and reliable energy technology for future applications due to its efficiency and convenience [7–9]. The process of electrochemical water-splitting involves two crucial reactions, oxygen evolution reaction (OER) on the anode and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on the cathode. The overall water-splitting reaction is demonstrated as follows: 2H2O (l) → 2H2 (g) + O2 (g). Water electrolysis can be performed in acidic, neutral and alkaline electrolytes. The standard thermodynamic potential of 1.23 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) in the alkali and acidic electrolyte media is required to split water into O2 and H2 [5,10]. However, due to multiple electron transfer steps involved in both cathodic and anodic reactions, the kinetics become sluggish, resulting in additional energy requirements known as overpotential (η) to overcome the reaction barriers and accelerate electron transfer. Therefore, electrocatalysts with high activity and robust stability are needed to enhance the kinetics of HER and OER for cost-effective water-splitting [11–13]. Generally, an efficient catalyst should fulfill two essential criteria: (1) the ability to generate high current density at small overpotential; (2) high operating stability. The performance of cost-effective catalysts based on transition metals in electrolytic water splitting, including metal organic framework (MOF), covalent organic frameworks (COF), high-entropy alloys, metal oxides and (oxy)hydroxides, diatomic catalysts, MXenes, etc., has been comprehensively summarized in previous cutting-edge reviews [14–31]. However, in a wide range of pH, especially in acid, noble metal catalysts are still considered as the most superior catalysts for both HER and OER. For instance, Pt/C and IrO2 widely serve as the HER and the OER benchmark, respectively. Thus, noble-metal based electrocatalysts are almost indispensable for these reactions [32,33]. Among various noble metals, Ru has gained significant attention as a cost-effective alternative within platinum-group metals and has shown great potential to substitute Pt in HER [34]. Ru exhibits comparable or even better HER performance to Pt, and possesses a bond strength with hydrogen similar to that of Pt (65 kcal mol−1) [35,36]. Moreover, Ru is more affordable than Ir, making it the most promising alternative to iridium oxide. According to the volcano theory proposed by Nørskov et al., RuO2 is localized near the peak of the volcano among extensively studied oxides, indicating its great potential as an ideal substitute for IrO2 in OER [37,38]. Therefore, ruthenium-based catalyst is the most promising catalyst for water splitting applications. Considerable efforts have been devoted to enhancing the water splitting activity and understanding the reaction mechanism of Ru-based catalysts, which results in the superior performance in comparison with commercial Pt/C and IrO2 catalysts [39–52]. However, the lack of ultra-long stability restricts the development of Ru-agent catalysts in electrolytic water splitting. Insufficient stability of Ru-based catalysts in HER can be attributed to phenomena such as Ostwald ripening, agglomeration, dissolution, and detachment [53,54]. In terms of OER reaction, stability remains one of the major challenges hindering its practical applications, as the transition from Ru4+ into soluble and losable Ru>4+ with higher valence states leads to the weak chemical stability and structural stability [39,55,56]. The stability of ruthenium catalysts for HER and OER is unsatisfactory due to above factors, necessitating further improvement. Although previous reviews have been made in terms of improving the activity of Ru-based catalysts in HER or OER, there is a noticeable lack of comprehensive one focusing on their stability issues in water splitting, necessitating attention and effective solutions to overcome limitations for practical applications [13,39,42]. It is an urgent need for a review encompassing critical aspects and recent advances in designing stable ruthenium-based catalysts for the hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions. In this review, we focus on the recent progresses in the stability of Ru-involving electrocatalysts for water splitting. First of all, we provide a brief introduction to the mechanisms of OER/HER reactions, evaluation methods and criteria for stability, as well as deactivation types for Ru-based materials. Subsequently, based on the recent advances in this field, we focus on the emphatic discussions of key issues and debate on stability, as well as stability-enhancing strategies via representing typical examples in HER and OER, respectively. In-depth analysis of high performance can provide valuable insights for designing superior catalysts. The development timeline of the stability of Ru-based catalysts, including several crucial stages, is provided in Fig. 2 . Finally, we address the challenges and prospects of utilizing Ru-based materials in water-splitting research field. Thus, this comprehensive review is expected to attract significant interest among researchers worldwide and stimulate further high-level investigations in this filed. Moreover, it is anticipated that this review will have significant implications on other catalytic fields, including photocatalysis, thermal catalysis and enzyme catalysis. 2 Fundamentals and principles of the stability 2.1 Fundamentals of electrochemical of water-splitting The understanding of the reaction mechanism in various electrolytes is crucial as it helps to enhance the reaction activity and stability. Numerous research studies have been carried out to investigate the reactions occurring on both electrodes during water-splitting. The proposed mechanisms are described as follows. 2.1.1 HER mechanism The generation of a single H2 molecule involves the participation of two electrons in the HER process, and its activation requires a theoretical thermodynamic voltage of 0 V when using an ideal catalyst. As a result, HER is typically carried out as a two-step, two-electron process, which can be represented by the following equations [57,58]. Acidic condition: Volmer step: H+ + e− → H* Heyrovsky step: H+ + H* + e− → H2 or Tafel step: H* + H* → H2 Alkaline and neutral conditions: Volmer step: H2O + e− → H* + OH− Heyrovsky step: H2O + H* + e− → H2 + OH− or Tafel step: H* + H* → H2 where * denotes the active sites of the electrocatalyst. HER can proceed via either the Volmer-Heyrovsky or Volmer-Tafel mechanism (Fig. 3(a) ) [58]. The rate-determining step can be identified by analyzing the Tafel slope, with values of 120, 40, and 30 mV dec−1 representing the Tafel slopes of Volmer, Heyrovsky and Tafel steps, respectively. For the formation of hydrogen, hydrogen adsorption and desorption are normally involved in the HER process [59]. Consequently, Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) can be a well-known descriptor calculated using density functional theory (DFT), which serves as a valuable tool to support experimental results. For an idea HER catalyst based on the Sabatier's principle, the ΔG H* ideally approaches zero, indicating that the hydrogen binding energy of the catalyst should be neither too weak nor too strong (Fig. 3(b)). If the hydrogen bond on the surface of the catalyst is excessively weak, the hydrogen cannot be sufficiently activated, conversely if the hydrogen bond is too strong, release of hydrogen becomes difficult and the occupation of the catalytic active sites prevents new hydrogen adsorption (Fig. 3(b)) [60,61]. The high electronegativity of Ru (Pauling scale = 2.2) leads to a strong adsorption of active hydrogen species (H*). It has been observed from the volcano plot that Ru exhibits a more negative ΔG H* about –0.2 eV compared to Pt (~0 eV), which results in an unfavorable desorption of hydrogen from Ru surface (Fig. 3(c)). Therefore, modulation of the electronic structure of Ru can be employed to remove the electrons from Ru, thereby enhancing its desorption ability towards hydrogen, and consequently improving the reaction rate of Heyrovsky or Tafel step. In alkaline media, the dissociation of water plays a pivotal role in Volmer step. The HER efficiency of Ru-based catalysts can be improved by accelerating the water dissociation through the promoted nucleophilic attack of water on the active center Ru. Generally, Ru exhibits a strong adsorption of hydroxyl, facilitating water dissociation on Ru, however, excessive adsorption strength leads to OH occupation of Ru sites, resulting in active site poisoning [59–61]. 2.1.2 OER mechanism Oxygen molecule generation in OER process requires the transfer of four electrons. Therefore, compared to HER, OER involves multiple steps with electron transfer, resulting in sluggish kinetics. The theoretical thermodynamic voltage for OER is 1.23 V [5,11,62]. Various OER mechanisms have been proposed due to the difficulty in detecting intermediates. One commonly suggested mechanism is the absorbate evolution mechanism (AEM, Fig. 4(a) ), where the oxygen precursors undergo a stepwise process involving adsorption-deprotonation-coupling- desorption in a typical proposed OER cycling [63–65]. The specific reaction process is shown in the following equations: Acidic condition: H2O → OH* + H+ + e− OH* → O* + H+ + e− O* + H2O → OOH* + H+ + e− OOH* → O2 + H+ + e− Alkaline and neutral conditions: OH− → OH* + e− OH* + OH− → O* + H2O + e− O* + OH− → OOH* + e− OOH* + OH− → O2 + H2O + e It is evident that the assumed AEM exhibits a characteristic of four concerted proton-electron transfer (CPET) reactions between the metal bands and the adsorbed oxygen intermediates, which can be considered as a type of metal redox catalytic reaction. However, AEM shows a strong correlation between binding energies of oxygen intermediates and activity. It exhibits a theoretical overpotential limitation of 370 mV, which cannot fully rationalize some advanced reports that demonstrate lower overpotential. As an alternative, researchers have proposed another advanced mechanism to achieve the oxygen evolution cycles more subtly. This mechanism involves the lattice oxygen redox chemistry and a direct (O–O) bond coupling in oxygen molecule production [65–68]. In this alternative pathway, oxygen ligands are electrochemically activated and released from the lattice matrix, following a lattice oxygen-mediated mechanism (LOM). However, there remain some debates regarding the precise process of LOM, mainly in the subsequent three aspects [65]. The pre-activated lattice oxygen can effectively perform as an active site, known as the oxygen-vacancy-site mechanism (OVSM, Fig. 4(b)), where it directly receives OH− via nucleophilic attack to form OOH* species. The release of the gaseous O2 product leads to the creation of an Ovac site, which is refilled by OH− [69]. Another mechanism (single-metal-site mechanism (SMSM, Fig. 4(c)) involves the utilization of a single metal site as the catalytic center for adsorbing OH−, followed by OH− deprotonation. The direct coupling of the O* intermediate and activated lattice oxygen forms OO* species, which is considered as a newly formed intermediate undergoing the subsequent oxygen release procedure [70,71]. A dual-metal-site mechanism (DMSM) has also been proposed as a supplement of LOM (Fig. 4(d)). As anticipated, adjacent activated lattice oxygen on dual-metal-site forms a M–OO–M motif via intramolecular oxygen coupling, where the resulting *OO* moiety typically functions as peroxo-like species [72,73]. Normally, the difference of binding free energy between OH* and O* (ΔG O*–ΔG OH*) in AEM is substantial, with a value of 3.2 ± 0.2 eV, according to previous study on numerous metal oxides [39]. Optimal OER catalysts should possess a moderate bonding to the O-related reaction intermediates, suggesting that excessively strong or weak binding energies are unfavorable for OER. By employing the first-principal calculation to determine the theoretical overpotential of numerous metal oxides against the binding free energy of ΔG O*–ΔG OH*, Rossmeisl and his co-workers established a scaling relation using the “volcano” model [45,62]. Among these catalysts, RuO2 theoretically possesses the highest activity toward OER, owing to the closest proximity to optimal bonding energy with oxygen species. However, it remains challenging to quantitatively correlate theoretical data with experimental observations. Some scholars believe that ruthenium oxide follows the LOM mechanism to explain the small overpotential, since it possesses active lattice oxygen and low oxygen vacancy formation energy. 2.1.3 DFT calculations Besides the experimental illustrations on the catalytic mechanism, a computational standard hydrogen electrode model based on DFT is constructed to simulate the thermochemistry of electrochemical reactions. DFT calculations can provide deeper insights into the electrochemical process occurring in Ru-based materials by calculating energy barrier. Zagalskaya et al. [55] found that the defective RuO x delivered a higher OER activity through the LOM pathway. AEM is preferred for the perfect RuO x (110) and (211) surfaces, while the formation of metal vacancies due to catalyst dissolution may lead to LOM with lower OER overpotentials. Additionally, dopants, such as Ni and Co, can promote LOM over AEM even on the perfectly structured surfaces. Projected density of states (PDOS) analysis can also explain catalytic activity trends across a variety of catalysts based on electronic-structure descriptors, such as transition metal d- and oxygen p-band centers. Specifically, the O 2p-band center can serve as a descriptor for the OER activities of metal oxides due to its ability to reflect the electronic structure properties of oxides, especially about the electrochemical steps occurring at the oxygen sites in OER. In the case of the OER, oxidation of oxygen becomes thermodynamically favorable when O 2p states at the materials Fermi level are positioned above the redox energy of the O2/H2O couple. The O 2p-band center clearly shifts towards more positive values and closer to the Fermi level when going from the ideal (110) to one- and two-vacancy surface models for RuO2, leading to enhanced OER activity. Additionally, computed DOS reveals that the d x2–y2-band center of Ni-doped RuO2 is shifted to a higher energy and closer to the Fermi level compared to the pure RuO2, making the LOM more preferable [55]. 2.1.4 In-situ characterization methods In-situ X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscope (TEM), Raman spectroscopy and other techniques are essential for real-time monitoring of phase structure changes, composite, morphology, vibrational change of M–O bond, defects, and other modifications. These analyses provide insights into the active sites and deepen our understandings of the roles of each component in catalysts. Particularly, operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAFS) offers a suitable investigative approach to capture the dynamic electronic structures, valence states and local coordination environments of catalysts during the reaction. Operando synchrotron Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) has been reported to successfully detect the intermediates OOH* and OO* of AEM and LOM, respectively. Differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) combined with isotope labeling has been employed to identify and quantify the products or intermediates during the reaction process, due to the simultaneous observation of electrochemical currents alongside mass spectrometer ion currents. The results obtained from this method solidly support whether the catalyst follows the AEM pathway or the LOM pathway [43,70]. Additionally, by employing an electrochemical flow cell (EFC) with an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS), simultaneous real-time measurement of metal dissolution quantities can be recorded alongside the electrochemical measurement for analyzing catalyst stability. As-synthesized metallic Ru sample exhibited dissolution rate approximately 10 times faster than that of the electrochemically produced RuO2 and about 100 times faster than that of the thermally produced RuO2. All ruthenium samples demonstrated massive dissolution at potentials exceeding the onset of the OER, which is approximately 1.4 V [44]. 2.2 Evaluation methods and criteria of stability Catalyst stability is also a crucial factor for practical applications that can be significantly influenced by various factors such as electrolyte properties. While most catalysts demonstrate good stability in alkaline media, their performance tends to be unsatisfactory in acidic media. This discrepancy is commercially significant. On the other hand, the method used to fabricate a working electrode, the structure, morphology and chemical properties of catalyst also affect the stability of catalyst. Normally, the active materials directly manufactured on working electrode are more stable compared to the pasted one. And the catalysts that possess a more stable structure, morphology and chemical properties tend to exhibit stable electrocatalytic performance. The two commonly employed stability testing methods are cyclic voltammetry (CV) and chronopotentiometry (CP; potential-time curve) or chronoamperometry (CA; current-time curve) [74–76]. Researchers also proposed various metrics such as Activity-Stability Factor (ASF), Activity-Durability Factor (ADF), and Stability number (S-number) to evaluate the stability of the catalyst [77–79]. However, it remains uncertain whether the stability reported in the laboratory settings can guarantee the long-term functionality on the actual device over several years, as there is no definitive way to determine the stability of the catalyst in real-world application. In spite of this, evaluating the stability of the catalyst in the laboratory remains an indispensable aspect for designing commercially viable catalysts. Recently, a set of techniques including ex-situ and in-situ XRD, TEM, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and scanning electron microscope (SEM) along with potentiometric studies are employed to investigate what is actually happening or the catalytic mechanism when the structure or composition of the catalyst are changed. These techniques also play roles in monitoring both the structural and compositional stability of catalysts [80–83]. 2.2.1 Chronoamperometry/chronopotentiometry The stability of catalysts can be assessed by using the CA or CP method over a long period at a constant potential or current density. In scientific literatures, CA is more commonly utilized than CP. During CA, the current density varies with time, and is carried out at a potential where the current density approaches 10 mA cm−2. The greater stability of the current density over time, the higher stability of the catalyst. The CP method is conducted at a consistent current density, typically 10 mA cm−2, with the measurement of potential variation. If there is a slight increase in overpotential, it indicates that the catalyst is stable. The stability test is recommended to be carried out at higher current densities (50 or 100 mA cm−2) for the catalysts with strong redox peaks. In order to approach industrialization, some researchers have tested the stability of catalysts at higher current density, such as 50, 100, 300 mA cm−2 and 1 A cm−2. In addition, evaluating stability under elevated temperatures (such as 40, 60, and 80 °C) also serves as a means to simulate real-world industrial applications [84]. 2.2.2 Cyclic voltammetry CV accelerates the degradation of electrocatalysts at a wide voltage window and higher scanning rates (such as 50 or 100 mV s−1). In general, the stability of the catalyst is determined by comparing linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves before and after several thousand CV cycles (1000–10000 cycles). If the LSV curve after CV cycles test almost coincides with the initial one or the overpotential slightly increases by less than 10% compared with the original values, it indicates favorable stability of the catalyst [85,86]. 2.2.3 Activity-stability factor The ratio between the rate of di-oxygen production (expressed as current density, J) and the rate of metal dissolution during OER (equivalent dissolution current density, S) proposed by Kim et al. [77] can accurately and effectively evaluate the activity and stability for a given material. Herein, the ASF represents this activity-stability metric by the following formula: A S F = J - S S | η where η represents a constant overpotential. The higher the stability of the OER catalysts, the higher the ASF value. In this method, the measurement of S was conducted utilizing an in-situ Stationary Probe Rotating Disk Electrode (SPRDE) coupled to an ICP-MS. 2.2.4 Activity-durability factor Li et al. [78] put forward a method to evaluate the stability performance of the catalysts by calculating the ratio between the H2 production rate (expressed as exchange current density, j ex) and the catalyst leaching rate (equivalent j corr). The catalyst leaching rate was measured by testing corrosion polarization curves of the catalysts. Similarly, a higher ADF value means better stability. A D F = j e x j c o r r 2.2.5 Stability number Geiger et al. [79] put forward a metric to determine the dissolution processes of various iridium-based oxides, which is defined as the ratio between the amounts of evolved oxygen and dissolved iridium based on a slow potential sweep: S - n u m b e r = n O 2 ( O E R ) n I r ( d i s s o l v e d ) where the production of oxygen was determined by calculating the total charge and the amount of dissolved Ir was tested by a combination of scanning flow cell (SFC) and ICP-MS. A larger S-number indicates better stability. The evaluation criteria do not depend on surface area, loading or active sites involved, providing a reasonable comparison of the stability among various materials. This assessment method is considered applicable and commonly employed to address the critical issue of metal dissolution in the Ru-based catalysts. 2.3 Deactivation mechanism 2.3.1 Deactivation mechanism for HER The stability of Ru-based nanomaterials is still questionable. It is essential to address issues such as metal leaching, irregular aggregation or detachment of active catalysts from the current collector during reaction conditions, especially under harsh conditions towards practical applications (i.e., 80 °C, 6 mol L−1 KOH). The stability of catalyst is closely related to its active site. The deactivation or loss of the active site will decrease the reaction rate and affect the lifespan of the catalyst. Therefore, it is crucial to design and prepare long-lasting catalysts based on an understanding of the deactivation mechanism. As shown in Fig. 5 , ruthenium-based catalysts typically become deactivated in HER reactions through various means: support corrosion, dissolution of the metal atoms, Osterwald ripening, agglomeration, particle detachment and active site poisoning [53,54]. Carbon support, which serves as the most common support will face the issue of corrosion under harsh electrochemical conditions, resulting in the agglomeration and dissolution of metal particles [86]. Similarly, acidic electrolytes can lead to the instability and corrosion of certain metal oxide supports. [87]. Moreover, the weak interaction between support and the loaded active species results in agglomeration and detachment of the active species during the reaction [88]. Harsh environmental conditions often trigger rapid deactivation especially at high temperature where the Ostwald ripening of Ru nanoparticles may occur [89,90]. Ostwald ripening involves the dissolution of small particles, solute directional migration, aggregation and deposition of those species onto large particles in an inhomogeneous particle system. This process is driven by the reduction of interface energy under certain temperature conditions. The agglomeration of nanoparticles to form larger particles is due to adsorption, electric charge and van der Waals force. Specifically, the surface of the nanoparticle may adsorb molecules, ions and proteins in the air, resulting in adsorption forces between the nanoparticles and consequent agglomeration. When the surface of the nanoparticles has opposite charges, it will produce a force that attracts each other of small particles and form larger ones. When nanoparticles are in close proximity, van der Waals forces can also cause the nanoparticles unification. In practical scenarios, the deactivation of catalysts typically arises from multiple factors, and these deactivation mechanisms coexist and exhibit mutual interactions with each other simultaneously. 2.3.2 Deactivation mechanism for OER Although Ru-based materials possess high activity, they face a significant challenge in terms of stability, especially in the OER electrocatalytic process. As the representative Ru-based catalyst for OER, RuO2 is unstable due to the dissolution caused by excessive oxidation at high overpotential above 1.4 V during OER process. The specific reaction can be described as follows: RuO2 + 2H2O → RuO4 (aq) + 4H+ + 4e− (U 0 = 1.39 V vs. RHE) [45,55,56]. Some researchers attribute the over-oxidation of Ru-based catalysts to the oxidation of lattice oxygen in the LOM mechanism, resulting in oxygen vacancies (VO) during OER. The formation of oxygen vacancies is accompanied with the exposure of Ru atoms on the surface, which will be over-oxidized to soluble high valence Ru>4+ (e.g. RuO4) materials. This excessive oxidation of Ru inevitably leads to the collapse of crystal structure and the destruction of stability [90–92]. Metallic Ru exhibits slightly better OER activity compared to RuO2, but its dissolution rate is 2–3 orders of magnitude higher than that of the oxide [93]. By employing SEM images, ICP analysis and electrochemical detection of RuO4, Paoli et al. [92] demonstrated that 90% of metal Ru was corroded from the catalyst electrode during continuous electrolysis at 1.5 V vs. RHE for 15 min, while approximately 30% dissolution was observed in the corresponding oxide during a measurement period lasting 15 hours. Moreover, it is notable that corrosion occurs in both alkaline and acidic electrolytes, and alkali exhibits even greater susceptibility compared to acid [94]. In addition, Mayrhofer et al. [44] conducted detailed comparative studies of the activity and stability of commonly used Ru, RuO2, Ir, and IrO2 in both acidic and alkaline media. The OER activities exhibit the following pattern: IrO2 < RuO2 ≈ Ir < Ru, whereas dissolution degree follows the trends of Ru ≫ Ir > RuO2 ≫ IrO2. It is worth noting that solely taking advantage of the high activity of ruthenium catalysts without improving their stability is impractical. 3 Recent advances in catalytic stability of Ru-based electrocatalysts for HER In recent times, there has been significant progress in the development of HER electrocatalysts using various of Ru-based materials including Ru metal, Ru oxides, Ru phosphides, Ru sulfides, Ru selenides, Ru single metal and other Ru-based complexes. This section summarizes some recent advancements and strategies to improve the stability of Ru-related materials with more detailed classifications. In order to make a more comprehensive understanding and comparison among their stability as HER catalysts, the latest breakthroughs in improving the stability of Ru-based catalysts for HER are summarized in Table 1 . 3.1 Incorporation of conductive substrate Most of the reported Ru-based catalysts for HER are in the formation of powders, necessitating the use of adhesives during catalytic electrodes preparation, which seriously impacts their conductivity and stability. In addition, irreversible agglomeration of powdered Ru nanoparticles is more likely to occur, leading to reduced utilization and catalytic performance [86,95]. Therefore, it would be beneficial to grow catalysts directly on a conductive substrate, such as carbon cloth (CC), nickel foam (NF), graphene aerogel and carbon nanofibers (CNF). This approach would strengthen both adhesion force and conductivity between the catalysts and the substrate, thereby improving activity and stability [96–101]. You et al. [96] synthesized Ru nanoparticles on carbon cloth using a facile glycerol-assisted solvothermal strategy (Ru-G/CC), which exhibited an enhanced HER performance with an overpotential of only 40 mV@10 mA cm−2 and maintained stability without significant changes in current density over a period of 100 h (Figs. 6(a)–(d) ). DFT calculations indicate that the free energy of H* (ΔG H*) at the active sites of Ru-G/CC (–0.20 eV) is lower than those of Ru (101) (–0.31 eV) and Pt (111) (–0.25 eV), owing to the amorphous/crystalline Ru structure decorated on CC. The electron transfer from Ru to the adsorbed H*, revealed by electron localized function (ELF) as well as the calculated density of states (DOS), led to the promoted performance for HER (Figs. 6(e) and (f)). By employing a facile and scalable dip coating and heating method, Zhang et al. [97] developed a hybrid catalyst consisting of RuO2 and NiO fabricated onto NF which exhibited excellent performance and required merely 18 mV overpotential to reach 10 mA cm−2. Moreover, the RuO2-NiO/NF catalyst exhibits a long-term electrolysis in cycling test for 20 h at 100 mA cm−2 with no obvious change in the morphology and the chemical states. The dissociation barrier of H2O at the RuO2-NiO interface is reduced to 0.09 eV, indicating the promotional effect of NiO on H2O dissociation and thus accelerating the production of H*. Moreover, the RuO2-NiO hybrid shows a lower ΔG H* compared to NiO and RuO2, suggesting that the formed interface can modulate the adsorption of H* and improve its HER activity. Tiny RuO2 was uniformly dispersed on NiO, enhancing the utilization efficiency of NiO. RuO2-NiO/NF was prepared by using formation of NiO from the support with excellent structural stability. The NiRu-based metal-organic framework (MOF) nanosheet arrays on a Ni foam substrate (NiRu-MOF/NF) were obtained by solvothermal reaction of Ni(NO3)2, RuCl3, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC), and triethylenediamine (TED) in the presence of a Ni foam substrate [98]. The optimized catalysts demonstrated decent catalytic performance for HER in alkaline conditions, requiring an overpotential of 51 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and exhibiting negligible decay during stability tests with a period of 24 h test at 30 mA cm−2. The excellent stability was ascribed to the enhanced contact between the electrocatalysts with MOF structure and electrode substrate by in-situ growth of NiRu-MOF on the backbone of the conductive NF. Additionally, the remarkable water stability of MOF structure also significantly contributed to its catalytic stability. Nitrogen‐doped graphene aerogel (N‐GA) also exhibits significant advantages as a support material of ultrafine Ru nanocrystals (Ru‐NCs). This nanocomposites catalyst synthesized by annealing 3D reduced graphene oxide, ruthenium chloride and polyallylamine, demonstrates remarkable performance, requiring overpotentials of only 52 and 36 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 HClO4 and 1 mol L−1 KOH electrolytes for HER process, respectively. The synergy effect between Ru and the highly conductive substrate, as well as the anchoring effect of the N atom contributed to the excellent stability of Ru‐NCs/N‐GA [99]. Amorphous phosphatized ruthenium-iron bimetallic nanoclusters supported on graphitized carbon nanofibers (RuFeP-NCs/CNF) synthesized by wet chemical reduction using sodium borohydride and subsequent phosphorization were reported to exhibit outstanding Pt-like HER performance with low overpotentials of 66 and 16.0 mV to deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in acidic and alkaline environments, respectively [100]. In addition, it displays exceptional stability by effectively catalyzing the HER for a minimum of 100 h with little performance attenuation and no aggregation and structural changes are observed in the clusters after the long-term stability tests (Figs. 7(a)–(e) ). RuFeP-NCs/CNF exhibits a small ΔG H* value of –0.11 eV, which is comparable to that of Pt (111) surface (−0.09 eV), explanationing for its Pt-like HER activity. Moreover, the ΔG OH*+H* value of RuFeP-NCs/CNF is merely –0.02 eV, suggesting a negligible barrier of water dissociation and H2 formation (Figs. 7(f)–(h)). The intimate interaction and facile electron transport between the RuFeP-NCs and CNF can firmly immobilize clusters and endow an enhanced stability during the HER process. N-doped carbon nanofibers were reported as a substrate by Zhou et al. [101] to anchor Ru nanoclusters with Mott-Schottky effect. The seamless attachment of Ru nanoclusters on the substrate can facilitate structural stability by preventing the active sites from unfavorable migration, aggregation, and detachment. Ru@N-CNFs presented low overpotentials of 16 and 17 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and nearly 20 h of stability tests in acidic and alkaline electrolytes, respectively. The Ru@NC heterostructure exhibits a ΔG H* value of –0.11 eV, which is smaller than that of the pristine Ru (–0.39 eV). Therefore, the formation of Ru@NC Schottky heterojunction can reduce the reaction energy barrier, thereby demonstrating its promising HER performance. It is evident that incorporating a conductive substrate significantly improves the stability of catalyst. The advantage lies in its direct utilization as a self-supporting electrode ensuring good mechanical stability and straightforward preparation process. However, the limited availability of suitable conductive substrates for use in acidic media poses significant challenges to design such catalysts. Therefore, further development of novel, stable and self-supporting conductive substrates is imperative. 3.2 Construction of core-shell structures Although Ru nanoparticles possess high activity, drawbacks such as agglomeration, leaching, oxidation and inactivation apparently compromise their stability. Among various strategies to overcome these drawbacks, introducing a protective layer on the surface of Ru nanoparticles to construct a core-shell structure becomes one of the effective solutions [102–105]. Ruthenium phosphides nanoparticles encapsulated within N,P-codoped hollow carbon nanospheres, which were synthesized by the confined phosphorization reaction between the aniline-pyrrole copolymer and guest RuP x exhibited good electrocatalytic HER activity in a wide pH range. Moreover, the shell could protect the active species from corrosion in the electrolyte so that the catalyst maintained a durability of 10 h [102]. Similarly, the amorphous turbostratic-phased carbon nitride (t-CN x ) layer was utilized not only as the modulator of electronic structures to trigger lower d-band position of Ru for the enhanced activity, but also as the protective layer to avoid the Ru aggregation/bleaching on multi-walled carbon nanotubes for improved stability [103]. Feng et al. [104] encapsulated Ru nanoparticle into an oxyfullerene-like carbon cage embellished with single-atomic RuN x species to construct a core-shell architecture by the coordination between Ru3+ ions and fullerenol in the presence of melamine and then thermal pyrolysis under Ar/H2 atmosphere (Figs. 8(a)–(f) ). This unique structure enables the catalyst to exhibit exceptional catalytic activity for HER, demonstrating continuously performance for at least 100 hours under both acidic and basic conditions. The DOS of RuNP@RuN4-FC possessed a lower d-band center of –3.75 eV compared to that of RuNP-RuN4/PC (–2.78 eV), indicating a weaker but more favorable hydrogen bonding strength. Additionally, the optimal hydrogen adsorption was calculated with a ΔG H* of –0.02 eV for RuNP@RuN4-FC (Figs. 8(g)–(i)). The protective coating on the surface is not limited to carbon-based materials, other materials can also be utilized. Ru nanoparticles encapsulated in a sulfur-modulated molybdenum oxide (MoO(S)3) shell were reported to show 63 and 30 mV overpotentials at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in acidic and alkaline media, respectively, which were synthesized by an oil-in-water strategy in a one-step hydrothermal reaction followed by annealing at 600 °C [105]. The catalyst showed excellent stability not only after undergoing 3000 CV cycles, but also operating in overall water-splitting devices with slightly decreased current density during 24 hours. This remarkable durability can be attributed to the encapsulation and protection of the active center Ru by the MoO(S)3 shell, which prevents erosion and electrochemical oxidation of Ru. The construction of core-shell structure represents a straightforward method, which can effectively address issues like particle agglomeration, dissolution and detachment. However, the preparation process is relatively complicated. The selection of an appropriate shell material plays a crucial rule; it should possess certain flexibility and mechanical strength, yet not impeding access to catalytic sites or hindering electrolyte permeation. 3.3 Formation of embedded structures As previously mentioned, the weak interaction between carbon support and metal, particularly in case of carbon as the most common support material, contributes to the insufficient stability of catalyst. Therefore, embedding Ru-based nanoparticles into the support becomes one of the effective solutions. Ruthenium nanoparticles embedded in N-doped mesoporous carbon nanospheres, S-doped RuP nanoparticles embedded in a N, P, and S-co-doped carbon sheet and heterostructured Ru-Ru2P nanoparticles embedded in the N, P-co-doped carbon nanofibers have been reported to exhibit good activity and stability [106–108]. Ru nanoparticles can be embedded within a nitrogenated holey two-dimensional carbon structure (Ru@C2N), which consists of uniformly distributed 0.83-nm-sized holes with six nitrogen atoms surrounding each hole to anchor Ru sites [109]. The Ru@C2N electrocatalyst exhibits small overpotentials at 10 mA cm−2 (13.5 mV in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 solution; 17.0 mV in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH solution) as well as superior stability (10000 cycles) in both acidic and alkaline media (Figs. 9(a)–(d) ). The high electrocatalytic activity of Ru@C2N originates from the optimal hydrogen binding energy, as revealed by DFT calculations. The RuMo-nanoalloys embedded in hexagonal 2D porous carbon (2DPC-RuMo) exhibit promising performance for HER with a small overpotential of 18 mV. These nanoalloys were synthesized by a combination of hard-templating synthesis and anion-exchange processes, enabling process control over both the geometric hexagonal morphology and alloy constitution [110]. This catalyst also shows robust stability with a negligible activity decay after undergoing 2000 cycles and 120 h (Figs. 9(e)–(g)). The introduction of N into C and Mo atoms into Ru lattices can reduce the energy barrier for the HER by inducing electron accumulation/depletion regions at the hetero-surface. The excellent electrocatalytic stability of the 2DPC-RuMo heterostructure can be attributed to the integration of stable RuMo nanoalloy particles within conductive N-rich hexagonal 2DPC nanosheets without any observable alternations in morphology, composition, or particle agglomeration. Li et al. [111] proposed that P, Mo dual doped Ru ultrasmall nanoparticles embedded in P-doped porous carbon are efficient for HER. The P,Mo-Ru@PC catalyst achieves a low overpotential of 21 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and presents excellent durability with an increase in overpotential of only 2 mV after 5000 cycles. The introduction of Mo and P atoms into Ru lattices triggers the in-situ electron donation from Ru to Mo and P, resulting in the optimized energies for water dissociation and near-optimal adsorption of hydrogen on P,Mo-Ru@PC catalyst and thereby reducing the energy barrier for the HER. It is evident that embedding Ru active species into carbon-based support serves as an effective approach to improve the stability of catalyst. Embedding into supports are not limited to carbon-based materials, but also applicable to other types of supports. Yu et al. [112] have reported that confining ultrafine Ru clusters into TiO2 lattice frameworks can both enhance the stability and intrinsic activity of Ru by a lattice-confined approach. Moreover, this catalyst delivers remarkable HER performance even under harsh conditions (80 °C and 6 mol L−1 KOH) with a small overpotential of 116 mV at 800 mA cm−2, and long-time stability for 200-h continuous HER at 300 mA cm−2 through the effective confinement of Ru (Figs. 9(h) and 9(i)). As disclosed by both experimental and computational results, the interaction between Ru and TiO2 can be enhanced by the lattice-confined strategy, which promotes the electron transfer from Ru to TiO2 and thus strongly stabilize Ru to avoid the dissociation and aggregation of Ru during the stability test. An electrocatalyst of ultra-small Ru nanoparticles embedded on Fe-Ni(OH)2 nanosheets in-situ grown on a Ni foam (RuFe@NF) was prepared by a one-step immersion method. Remarkably, this catalyst only requires an overpotential of 28 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 towards the HER [113]. Moreover, the RuFe@NF based electrolytic cell exhibits ultra-long stability over 680 h at 10 mA cm cm−2 and even at higher current density up to 100 mA cm−2. The excellent catalytic performance of the catalyst can be attributed primarily to the special structure of Ru nanoparticles embedded in Fe-Ni(OH)2 nanosheets. Anchoring the particles with this method can enhance their stability on the support. However, characterizing the structure to confirm that the particles are embedded in the support remains challenging. Moreover, only exposed part of the particle serves as catalytic sites, reducing atomic utilization. There is no obvious rule in the selection of the support that can construct the embedded structure, necessitating the development of a universal method for such constructions. 3.4 Enhancement of the metal-support interaction Supported metal catalysts play an important role in heterogeneous catalytic reactions due to their flexibility and adjustability. While carbon support is a commonly used support, the interaction between carbon and the loaded active species is normally weak, leading to the aggregation or even detachment of the active species during the reaction process and resulting in insufficient stability [114–117]. To address this issue, researchers have developed oxygen-coordinated single-atom iron sites (Fe-O4) decorated carbon nanotubes with abundant vacancies as the support to stabilize Ru clusters. The synthesis of these clusters involved an iron-induced functionalization strategy, followed by subsequent electrochemical reduction. This innovative catalyst demonstrated an overpotential of only 64 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a durability of 20 h in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 solution [118]. The synergistic combination of vacancy defects and iron single-atom sites not only promotes the charge redistribution of Ru clusters and optimizes the adsorption energy of H*, but also enhances the metal-support interaction at the interfaces of Ru cluster-support, leading to superior structural and catalytic stability, thereby resulting in remarkable HER performance. Another study by Li et al. [119] utilized C60 fullerenol (C60(OH)24) to stabilize, disperse, and activate Ru nanoparticles through Ru–O–C60 connections, which were synthesized by integrating wet chemistry reactions, freeze-dried techniques, and pyrolysis processes. The anchoring and confinement effects of C60 fullerenols allow for dense and uniform dispersion of Ru nanoparticles on the C60 substrate. The synthesized Ru-OC60-300 showed an ultra-small overpotential of 4.6 mV at 10 mA cm−2 along with excellent performance during 50 h chronopotentiometry test that showed only a slightly increase in overpotential by 13.3 mV (Figs. 10(a)–(e) ). The high electronegativity of the O atom and the electron-withdrawing property of C60 electrons trigger electron transferring from Ru NPs to C60 through O atoms, resulting in the strong interaction between Ru NP and C60. It optimizes the HER kinetics of Ru-OC60 through the strong H2O adsorption, rapid H2O dissociation, and appropriate H* adsorption. In addition, a series of supported metal catalysts with strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) have been developed as alternatives to the carbon support. The ideal support in electrocatalysis should possess good electrical conductivity. It serves not only as a physical support for anchoring the active site, but also has strong interaction with the active species, which can induce the charge redistribution on the metal-support interface and stabilize the supported metal [120]. Irregularly curved Ru nanorods supported on porous and hollow titanium nitride nanosheet assembled tubes (Ru NRs/TiN) exhibited excellent activity with an overpotential of only 25 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 [121]. No degradation in performance is observed after 10000 CV cycles, while Ru NRs/C experienced an irreversible performance loss. The CP measurement further reflected the high stability of Ru NRs/TiN, which showed an attenuation of only 41 mV after a 50-h test compared to reductions of 115 and 135 mV for Ru NRs/C and Pt/C, respectively. Unlike Ru NRs/C catalyst, Ru particles aggregate to a certain extent, while no significant change is observed in the morphology of Ru NRs/TiN catalyst. The SMSI between Ru nanorods and TiN can be confirmed by the density functional theory calculations. The significant charge redistribution at the Ru-TiN interface implies the strong interaction between the supported Ru and TiN slab (Figs. 10(f)–(j)). Molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) has been widely utilized as a support for active metal catalysts in various reactions due to its excellent chemical, mechanical and thermal stability. However, the weak bonding between the active metal catalyst and molybdenum carbide leads to irreversible agglomeration and dissolution loss during the catalytic process, resulting in inadequate stability [122,123]. To address this issue, Yu et al. [124] regulated the bonding between Ru single atoms and Mo2C nanosheets (Ru SAs/N-Mo2C NSs) substrate by introducing nitrogen doping of Mo2C through the anti-Ostwald ripening. The anti-Ostwald ripening method can enhance the interaction between the single atom and the support, rendering a more stable dispersion of Ru at atomic level. The catalyst showed superior catalytic stability for HER in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH, with a decay of only 3.7% over 8 h and a 6.3% decay over 60 h at an overpotential of 100 mV. In addition, the catalyst demonstrated remarkable catalytic performance over 60 h at overpotentials of and 230 mV, achieving high current densities of approximately 80 and 150 mA cm−2, respectively. The morphology remains almost unchanged and Ru loading amount verifies the enhanced electrocatalytic stability, which can be contributed to the strong interactions between the Ru SAs and N-Mo2C NSs substrate. Theoretical calculations reveal that the synergistical acceleration of H2O dissociation, combined with optimized H* adsorption strength in Mo-Ru interface, facilitates enhanced HER activity of Ru SAs/N-Mo2C NSs. The confinement effect and strong interaction between the surface hydroxyl group and single atoms make layered metal hydroxides (LMHs) promising supports with high-loading capacity of single atomic metal [125,126]. Chen et al. [127] synthesized nickel hydroxide ultrathin nanoribbons on nickel foam with atomically dispersed Ru atoms, which exhibited an overpotential of 16 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. The catalytic stability of R-NiRu was confirmed through extensive testing, including 5000 cycles of CV cycling test and continuous working for 12 h. The exceptional stability can be attributed to the bonding and anchoring effect between abundant surface hydroxyl groups in the nanoribbon structure and the Ru atoms. The WO3 matrix can also support single atomic Ru, which exhibits overpotentials of 28.0 mV in acidic media, 17.6 mV in alkaline media, and 83.0 mV in neutral media to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 as well as robust stability for 100 h at ampere-level current density [128]. The strong electronic interaction between Ru and WO3 can be achieved by electron transfer from W sites to nearby Ru site through a bridging O atom. This robust interaction plays a vital role in preventing Ru sites from agglomeration and achieving moderate H* adsorption, hence significantly contributing to its outstanding performance. The synthesis of catalysts with enhanced metal-support interaction is generally expedient. Especially, the combination of a single Ru atom onto supports not only reduce the ruthenium usage, but also improves its atomic utilization, making it one of the most promising approaches for industrialization. Generally, supports functionalized with specific groups can enhance metal-support interaction. Carbon-based support is commonly employed; however, it exhibits stability issues at high applied voltages. Other supports suffer from low conductivity, which restricts their catalytic performance. Therefore, developing highly conductive and stable supports in acidic or basic electrolytes under high external voltages becomes crucial. 3.5 Phase engineering Crystal phase engineering can also significantly enhance electrochemical stability because of the robustness of the crystal structure with various bond lengths and coordination numbers [129]. The synthesis of Ru-based nanomaterials with face-centered-cubic structure (fcc) has posed a significant challenge due to their high systemic energy. Zhang et al. [130] synthesized fcc-structured RuCu hollow urchin-like nanospheres (fcc-RuCu HUNSs) by a wet-chemical strategy. The fcc-RuCu HUNSs only require an overpotential of 26 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH for HER, which efficiently surpasses that observed in materials with hexagonal close-packed (hcp) phase. Moreover, the stability exhibited by fcc phase outperforms its hcp counterpart. In the study conducted by Li et al. [131], Ru nanodendrimers modified by MoO x with pure fcc phase (MoO x -Ru fcc) were synthesized via a colloidal method. The similar catalysts with hcp phase can be obtained by undergoing a phase transformation through high-temperature annealing in an inert Ar atmosphere. MoO x -Ru fcc exhibited significantly higher activity and greater stability in catalyzing HER compared to the MoO x -Ru hcp catalyst. The current of MoO x -Ru fcc experienced a minimal decrease of only 6.6% after 20000 s, while the activity of MoO x -Ru hcp dropped by 23.5% at 10000 s, indicating significantly higher stability of fcc phase (Figs. 11(a)–(c) ). With the modification effect of MoO x , ɛ d of the (111) facet of Ru with fcc phase was reduced to –2.70 eV, resulting in the lowest adsorption energy of protons and hydroxyl groups. The moderate adsorption energies of H* and OH* on MoO x -Ru fcc (ΔG H* = –0.30 eV; ΔG OH* = –0.07 eV) further confirmed the superior HER capability of the fcc phase Ru (Figs. 11(d)–(i)). Kim et al. [132] observed the formation of a novel phase of ruthenium carbide (RuC X , X < 1) on the surface of the Ru nanocrystal during exothermic phase-transition from cubic-close-packed (ccp) to hcp structure. The ccp{111} and hcp{002} are considered as close-packed planes, which exhibit stacking sequences of ABC and ABAB, respectively, along with their corresponding packing directions. Consequently, the ccp-to-hcp phase-transition can be understood as the formation of the Ruhcp(002) plane due to the slippage of the Ruccp(111) plane. During the phase-transition, the RuC X phase can be formed. According to the HER activity and stability tests in alkaline media, catalysts with RuC X phase on the surface exhibited superior performance compared to those with ccp and hcp phases, delivering an overpotential 97 mV at a current density of 50 mA cm−2 and minimal degradation of operating potential at 10 mA cm−2 over a period of 12 h. DFT calculations predict that the local heterogeneity of the outermost RuC X surface and high coverage of atomic-level interfaces promote the bifunctional HER mechanism by providing catalytic sites for both H* adsorption and facile water dissociation (Figs. 12(a)–(g) ). Phase transformation is an effective approach for selecting the stable phase structure of ruthenium and improving the intrinsic stability. The fcc phase structure is relatively more stable for ruthenium. However, this method typically involves high temperatures to induce phase transition, which may lead to Osterwald ripening and agglomeration, resulting in larger particles that could potentially compromise the activity and stability of catalysts. Therefore, it is imperative to explore alternative methods for achieving phase transition at lower temperatures. 3.6 Modulations of adsorption and desorption behavior of intermediates Ru is considered as a feasible electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution due to its rapid dissociation of water in alkaline electrolytes. However, the strong affinity of Ru towards adsorbing hydroxyl (OHad) can lead to the poisoning of active sites, thereby impacting the activity and stability of the catalyst [124,133,134]. The selenium-enriched RuSe2 (Ru x Se) nanocrystals were prepared by a simple hydrothermal reaction followed by thermal annealing process, exhibiting remarkable performance as a highly efficient HER electrocatalyst in alkaline media with a low overpotential of 45 mV and a high stability of 18 h [135]. The excessive Se would reduce the energy barrier for water dissociation and weaken the dependence on the Ru sites for OH* adsorption while have a negligible effect on the energy required for hydrogen adsorption. Study by Chen et al. [136] involving depositing Ru nanoparticles on strong reductive Ti(III) oxide (r-TiO2) with oxygen vacancies, resulting in a minimal overpotential of merely 15 mV to deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 while experiencing only slight degradation of HER activity over 10 h. DFT calculations indicate that the electron transfer occurs from Ru clusters to the pristine TiO2(110) in the Ru(0001)/TiO2, resulting in the positively charged Ru clusters. By contrast, for the Ru(0001)/r-TiO2, there is an opposite electron transfer from the partially reduced TiO2(110) to the Ru clusters, leading to the negatively charged Ru. Moreover, the reduction of TiO2 can promote water dissociation and weaken the adsorption strength of OH, thereby promoting the continuous water dissociation and hydrogen production (Figs. 13(a)–(f) ). The synergistic effect of Ru and RuO2 interfaces, which was achieved through a precipitation method followed by annealing under an oxygen-poor environment and/or in-situ electrochemical reduction, was reported to enhance water adsorption and dissociation as well as optimize OH binding energy [137]. The formed Ru/RuO2 interfaces presented superior HER performance, achieving 10 mA cm−2 with an overpotential of 17 mV, and maintained stability for up to 300 h of testing at the same current density without any noticeable degradation. Zhang et al. [138] regulated the strong adsorption between Ru and OHad by introducing SnO2 to perform competitive adsorption on OHad. This approach helps to moderate the poisoning of Ru active site. Theoretical calculation revealed that the binding energy of OHad on Ru sites (1.06 eV) exhibits a weaker interaction with OHad than that of Sn sites (0.36 eV) for the Ru SAs/SnO2, which indicated a preference of OH adsorption on SnO2. As a consequence, the presence of Ru SAs-SnO2/C exhibited a low overpotential of 17 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and an excellent stability after 3000 CV cycles and continuous testing for 27 h. Therefore, the competitive adsorption of OHad between Ru and SnO2 facilitated the OHad transfer process, which effectively alleviated the poisoning of Ru sites and accelerated the regeneration of Ru active sites (Figs. 14(a)–(e) ). Regulating the adsorption and desorption of intermediates is an effective way to mitigate catalytic site poisoning. In alkaline media, the strong hydroxyl adsorption on Ru sites can lead to Ru poisoning, thus adjusting the adsorption strength of hydroxyl on active sites can enhance the catalytic performance. Introducing another catalytic site for adsorption of hydroxyl is also beneficial. However, this approach primarily focuses on hydroxyl poisoning, with limited reports on other ions. Considering practical applications or seawater or wastewater electrolysis, where purity of the electrolyte is relatively low, competitive adsorption with other ions on the catalyst surface becomes a concern. Therefore, further investigations are expected to regulate the adsorption and desorption of intermediates to prevent other ions from poisoning catalytic sites. In summary, according to the recent advancements on the stability of Ru-based catalysts for HER, the strategies for improving the stability can be divided into the following six types: incorporation of conductive substrate, construction of core-shell structures, formation of embedded structures, enhancement of the metal-support interaction, phase engineering, and modulations of adsorption and desorption behavior of intermediates (Fig. 15 ). The timeline shows that every design strategy is out of date. The deactivation mechanisms of various catalysts for HER can be attributed to support corrosion, dissolution of the metal atoms, Osterwald ripening, agglomeration, particle detachment and active site poisoning. Generally speaking, the poor stability is not dependent on a single factor but rather multiple ones, which even trigger a cascading effect. The design of catalysts necessitates simultaneous suppression of various causes of inactivation; hence, the aforementioned strategies can be employed in a cross-disciplinary manner. Therefore, the principles underlying the design process for stable Ru-based catalyst in HER lie in selecting Ru particles and supports with stable phase structures, immobilizing Ru on the support, optimizing the adsorption of the intermediate by modulating the electronic structure of the Ru, and culminating an efficient and stable Ru-based catalyst. 4 Recent advances on catalytic stability of Ru-based electrocatalysts for OER Currently, Ru-based materials including Ru metal, Ru oxides, Ru-based perovskites, Ru-based pyrochlores and other Ru-based hybrids have been widely designed and synthesized as OER electrocatalysts. As mentioned, inadequate stability remains the prominent problem of RuO2 in acidic electrolytes, which is mainly ascribed to the oxidation of Ru atoms resulting in soluble high-valence states. Moreover, the oxidation-induced collapse and loss of the active species can lead to the observed decayed stability. In principle, the stability of Ru-based catalysts can be effectively improved by stabilizing or preventing the formation of the high-valence states of Ru and improving the stability of crystal structure. This section summarizes some recent advances and strategies to improve the stability of Ru-related materials with more detailed classifications. In order to provide a more comprehensive understanding and comparison among different samples used as Ru-based OER catalysts, Table 2 summarizes recent advances in their stability. 4.1 Hybridization of Ru-based catalysts with iridium Ir-based catalysts exhibit superior stability compared to Ru-based catalysts. Incorporating Ir and Ru together is one of the effective ways to improve the stability of Ru-based catalysts [148–150]. Shan et al. [148] reported a heterostructured OER electrocatalyst with a highly strained ruthenium core and a partially oxidized iridium shell via a sequential polyol method. The as-prepared Ru@IrO x nanostructure can offer an overpotential of 282 mV to deliver 10 mA cm−2 together with an activity retention of 90% over a 24 h test in acidic environments. The enhanced electrocatalytic activity of the Ru@IrO x core-shell nanocrystals were attributed to the favorable surface valence states due to the charge redistribution at the metal core-oxide shell heterojunction. The excellent catalytic durability was ascribed to both stable chemical states and core-shell nanostructure. Specifically, these factors prevented the formation of the dissolvable high-valent intermediate species during the OER process and core-shell structure provides effective protection over active Ru sites from electrolyte loss. The intermetallic Ru1Ir1O x nanocatalyst was synthesized by He et al. [149], which exhibited a low overpotential of 204 mV (10 mA cm−2) and continuous OER electrolysis of at least 110 h (100 mA cm−2) with negligible changes in acidic electrolyte. Compared to RuO x , Ru1Ir1O x exhibited a significantly higher S-number (1.13 × 106 vs. 1.99 × 103) at 10 mA cm−2 after 20 h OER test. The d-band center of –1.68 eV and charge density difference in Ru1Ir1O x confirmed the tailored electronic structures of Ir sites and Ru sites by charge redistribution. The values of ΔG of various intermediates suggested that the intermetallic Ru1Ir1O x possessed the optimal adsorption energy of the intermediates for acidic OER. The stability was enhanced owing to the synergistic effects between Ru and Ir atoms by charge redistribution and structural enhancement (Figs. 16(a)–(g) ). Another efficient catalyst in acid was reported as well, known as solid-solution Ru-Ir nanosized-coral (RuIr-NC) consisting of 3 nm-thick sheets with only 6 wt% Ir [150]. RuIr-NC required only 165 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 and showed a lifetime of 122 h under a constant current density of 1 mA cm−2. The coral-like structure, characterized by exposed {0001} facets with the lowest surface energy of hcp structures and excellent resistance to oxidation, contributes to its high-performance by inhibiting the formation of the dissolvable metal oxides. The original intention behind the combination of ruthenium with iridium is to take advantage of the remarkable activity of ruthenium coupled with the exceptional stability of iridium. The ruthenium oxide and iridium oxide share a similar rutile crystal structure with lattice matching, enabling a stable catalyst formation. However, there remains room for improvement in terms of the stability of iridium. Despite this limitation, in view of its widespread usage in acidic media of iridium, this approach remains significant. By employing specialized structural and morphological designs, the synergistic effects of Ir and Ru can be achieved. 4.2 Construction of core-shell structures Introducing a protective layer on its surface and construct a core-shell structure proves to be an effective way to encapsulate and protect Ru-based cores [151–154]. One of the most common pathways is to wrap carbon. Cui et al. [151] enhanced the activity and stability of Ru nanoparticles by encapsulating them into controllable oxidation of graphene (RuNi2©G-250) by a hard template impregnation method. An overpotential of only 227 mV and a lifetime of 24 h at 10 mA cm−2 was achieved in acidic electrolyte. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) indicated the Ru dissolution percentage relative to the initial mass loading was approximately 1.5% and Ru K-edge indicated the electronic structure and valence state of Ru in RuNi2©G-250 sample after stability test almost had no change compared with the fresh catalyst. DFT calculations reveal that the interfacial Ru centers between RuO2 and graphene can disrupt the conventional scaling relationships governing the free energies of HOO* and HO*, leading to a modification in the rate-determining step and a reduction in energy barrier. Consequently, the enhanced intrinsic OER activity of RuO2 was observed. Additionally, charge transfer from the graphene to RuO2 implied that the graphene could serve as an electron reservoir to donate electrons to RuO2 surface, thereby enhancing the resistance against the over-oxidation and corrosion for RuO2 (Figs. 17(a)–(h) ). Ultrathin nitrogen-doped carbon was reported by Yan et al. [152] to protect oxygen-vacancy (Vo·) rich RuO2 nanoparticles on carbon nanotubes (CNTs). NC@Vo·-RuO2/CNTs-350 required an overpotential of 170.0 mV to achieve 10.0 mA cm−2 and showed a stability of 900 h without any distinguishable activity loss. The DFT calculations indicate that the strong electronic coupling between the NC/CNTs and the RuO2 NPs, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of RuO2. The presence of Vo· can strengthen the electronic coupling and improve both the stabilities of lattice oxygen and surface Ru during the OER processes. Additionally, the ultrathin NC shell serves as a protective layer against the chemical corrosion of RuO2 NPs during the OER. This catalyst demonstrates an impressive S-number value of approximately 4.5 × 106. The stability of Ru oxides surpasses that of metallic Ru, thus enabling the effective utilization of oxide species as a protective shell. Wang et al. [153] reported a novel architecture with a core of ultrathin metallic RuRh nanosheets and a shell of RuO2/RhO2 oxides as electrocatalysts toward the OER. The RuRh@(RuRh)O2 core/shell nanosheets can achieve a 245 mV overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 and maintain a current density of 5 mA cm−2 for 8000 s. DFT calculations unravel the superior OER performance based on the electro-activation by the surface oxidation layer. The core RuRh preserves the high electrical conductivity for electron transfer towards the surface, while the shell RuO2 layer further pumps the electrons towards the adsorbates to efficiently, facilitating the consecutive reactions for OER. The RuO2/RhO2 oxides shell protects the normally labile RuRh NSs core against dissolution. Harzandi et al. [154] achieved similar protection by safeguard the metallic NiRu-core through employing oxidized Ru-shell with Ni single atoms, resulting in an overpotential of 184 mV and a lifetime of 30 h at 10 mA cm−2. The extensive Ni leaching from the catalyst surface through hot acid treatment formed the stabilized metal vacancies, leading to increased interaction with adsorbates via acid-base O–O bond formation and shorter Ru–O bond distances and thereby enhancing the catalytic activity and protecting the Ru material against dissolution. Constructing a core-shell structure to encapsulate and safeguard ruthenium represent effective strategies for inhibiting the over-oxidation and dissolution of ruthenium. Similar to HER, the fabrication process of this structure is relatively intricate. The selection of an appropriate shell is crucial. It is imperative that the chosen shell exhibits both flexibility and mechanical strength, while also allows electrolyte penetration without obstructing access to catalytic sites. In particular, in acidic media, there is a scarcity of suitable materials for constructing shells. Therefore, developing novel shell materials that possess enhanced stable without compromising catalytic activity becomes pivotal. 4.3 Incorporation of stable support A viable approach to improve the dissolution resistance of Ru-based OER catalysts is anchoring the Ru active sites in a conductive matrix, thereby avoiding the dissolution of Ru [155–162]. The graphdiyne (GDY) serving as support material can enhance the activity and stability of Ru atom catalyst [155]. The incorporation of GDY in Ru/GDY has an overpotential of 531 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 with only minimal degradation observed during 2000 CV cycles and a 54-h chronoamperometric test. The superior stability can be ascribed to the robust nature of GDY skeleton and the strong coupling between the individually anchored Ru atoms and GDY. DFT calculations indicate that the strong p–d coupling between Ru atoms and adjacent C atoms produces an intrinsic electron compensation library to stabilize the high oxidation of anchored Ru. Carbon nitride-derived N-C can also serve as an efficient matrix to support single-atomic Ru [156]. The single-atom Ru-N-C catalyst with atomically anchored Ru1-N4 site delivered an overpotential of 267 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a dissolution ratio of 5% after 30-h operation in acidic environment. The combination of in-situ XAFS and FTIR revealed the dynamic pre-adsorption of O to give the O-Ru1-N4 structure with more charge donations of Ru under operando conditions. Theoretical calculations demonstrated that this newly formed O-Ru1-N4 site delivered a low barrier of O–O coupling, facilitating the formation of the OOH* intermediate. A metal organic framework (MOF) derived carbon (CoNC) was reported by Xu et al. [157] to support ruthenium-iridium (RuIr) nanocrystals, which showed an overpotential of 223 mV at 10 mA cm−2 during continuous OER electrolysis lasting up to 40 h with a S-number of 1.01 × 105. DFT calculations revealed that RuIr nanocrystals could lower the potential barrier of the rate determining step. Moreover, the CoNC support with the pyrrolic-N sites endowed homogeneous dispersion and robust immobilization of RuIr catalysts, thereby enhancing their resistance to dissolution during the acidic OER (Figs. 18(a)–(f) ). Conventional carbon supports are most widely deployed in electrocatalysis, but they suffer from severe oxidation under the high OER operation voltage. In addition to carbon-based supports, metal oxides, layered double hydroxides (LDH) and MOF supports are regarded as the promising candidates. It was reported by Wang et al. [158] that the oxygen vacancies were enriched by dispersing RuO2 over defective TiO2 (D-TiO2), which could modulate the electronic structure of Ru and enhance the conductivity of the catalyst. As a result, the as-prepared RuO2/D-TiO2 catalyst exhibited a low overpotential of 180 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a long lifetime above 100 h at 200 mA cm−2 with a leaching of ~17.30 at% Ru (Figs. 18(g)–(k)). The electronic structure of RuO2 is successfully modulated by the defective TiO2 support enriched with oxygen vacancies, and thereby reduce the energetic barrier. Similarly, oxygen-defective Co3O4 can also anchor atomically dispersed Ru single-atom, which exhibited an overpotential of 280 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a long-term stability of 150 h in alkaline media [159]. The enhanced Raman characteristic peaks of Ru/Co3O4–x measured at 1.5, 1.6, 1.7, and 1.1 V indicated that the atomically dispersed Ru improved the structural stability of Co3O4–x during OER for the strong electron coupling effects between Ru and Co3O4–x supports. DFT calculations uncovered that oxygen vacancy and atomically dispersed Ru could synergistically tailor electron decentralization and d-band center of Co atoms, further optimizing the adsorption of oxygen-based intermediates and reducing the reaction barriers of OER. The improved stability was ascribed to the strong electron coupling effect between Ru atoms and Co3O4–x substrates. Single atomic Ru anchored on Fe2+ ions doped NiFe LDH has been reported to exhibit a reduced overpotential of 194 mV at 10 mA cm−2, along with negligible performance decay and dissolution even after 100 h stability test at 100 mA cm−2 [160]. Only 0.46 ppb dissolved Ru can be detected by ICP-MS after 24 h electrolysis in the electrolyte for the catalyst, which is considerably lower than the concentration observed for RuO2 (53 ppb). The prominent stability can be attributed to the strong electronic interaction between Ru and Fe2+ and the decreased valence states of both the Fe and Ru sites. A ternary amorphous/crystalline FeCoNi LDH, which serves as an efficient support of single Ru atoms, was also be reported by Hu et al. [161]. The amorphous outer layer decorated by abundant unsaturated coordination sites and defect sites, which utilize as anchoring sites to stabilize single Ru atoms. A highly symmetric rigid structure can be observed in crystalline inner, thereby strengthening the stability of support during OER. The combination of synergistic effects gives this hybrid catalyst with a low overpotential of 205 mV and a 48-h continuous testing without any noticeable decay. Yao et al. [162] developed a metal-organic framework UiO-67-bpydc (bpydc represents 2,2’-bipyridine-5,5’-dicarboxylic acid) with strong coordinating pyridine ligands as support to anchor atomically isolated Ru oxide by hydrothermal growth of UiO-67-bpydc and followed Ru anchoring process. Ru-UiO-67-bpydc not only displayed an overpotential of 200 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2, but also showed a long-term stability lasting up to 115 h. Electrochemical experiments, including isotope tests, in-situ Raman, and in-situ 18O-labeled DEMS, validated the participation of lattice oxygen in OER through the LOM pathway. Theory calculations and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) characterizations revealed that the soluble *Vo-RuO4 2– intermediate and activated lattice oxygen could be stabilized by Ru–N bonds formed between Ru oxide and UiO-67-bpydc, thereby enhancing both OER stability and performance (Figs. 19(a)–(g) ). The introduction of stable support represents an effective approach to reduce the amount of ruthenium and stabilize the ruthenium site, and it is also a promising method that is expected to be industrialized. However, ruthenium remains vulnerable with a tendency to be over-oxidized and dissolved. Therefore, it is necessary to develop highly conductive support that exhibits stability in acidic electrolytes under high-voltage environment. Additionally, achieving coating during the introduction of the support holds great potential for significantly enhancing the catalyst stability, which presents a direction for future development. 4.4 Chemical doping Doping catalysts with certain elements is an efficient approach to modify their electronic structure, thereby adjusting the activity and stability. Previous reports have demonstrated that doping RuO2 with non-precious transition metal cations such as Cr, Fe, Mn, Ni, Co, and Zn leads to improved OER performance [163–167]. The sulfate anion and Fe cation co-doped RuO2 (S-RuFeO x ) with high OER activity and stability in acid was reported by Xue et al. [164]. This catalyst displayed a comparable OER performance with a low overpotential of 187 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in acid conditions, and much enhanced stability with 5000 cycles of CV test and 50 h of CP test at 1mA cm−2. Notably, only a minimal dissolution rate of 4.4% for Ru was observed after subjecting the S-RuFeO x catalyst after 5000 cycles. The doping effect not only promotes the deprotonation of water molecule and weakens the adsorption energy of the OOH* intermediate, but also stabilizes lattice oxygen and improves the stability of the catalyst. Mn-doped ultrathin Ru nanosheet branches (RuMn NSBs) were reported to show an overpotential of 226 mV in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 and 222 mV in 1 mol L−1 KOH at 10 mA cm−2 [165]. Moreover, these RuMn NSBs demonstrate remarkable stability in water splitting, with a lifespan reaching up to125 h in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4. DFT calculations have demonstrated that the introduced Mn improves the stability of valence states in Ru sites due to the compensatory electronic structures. An et al. [166] synthesized a series of Ru-based alloys by doping with Co, Cr, Zn, and Mn on carbon fiber papers. CV cycle test was applied as a dealloying treatment and surface transformation strategy. Notably, the RuMn alloy showed remarkable resistance against acid corrosion and overoxidation during 20000 cycles, whereas other Ru-based samples (Ru, RuCo, RuCr, RuZn) deteriorated rapidly within only 10 consecutive CV cycles.
