In addition, RuMn catalyst remained stable for 720 h during CP test at 10 mA cm−2. A surface reconstruction process that formed a robust amorphous RuO x surface was beneficial for the superior stability, which can be attributed to the high bond strength between Ru atoms within RuMn alloy (Figs. 20(a)–(e) ). According to the previous research by Wu et al. [167], the addition of Ni dopants can also enhance the lattice stability of both surface Ru and subsurface oxygen. Ni-RuO2 catalysts an overpotential of 214 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a 200 h of continuous operation. The S-number was found to be 7.4 × 105 after 205 h of testing for Ni-RuO2. Operando DEMS analysis confirmed that Ni-RuO2 catalysts underwent an AEM pathway. The limiting potential of OER on the Ni-RuO2 (110) surface was calculated to be 1.70 V, which was approximately 0.2 V lower than that of RuO2, indicating the improved OER activity of Ni-RuO2. The incorporation of Ni into the lattice resulted in an increased energy cost for Ru demetallation from 1.87 to 2.22 eV, suggesting a more stable surface Ru in Ni-RuO2 compared to pure RuO2 alone. Furthermore, the enthalpy changes for subsurface oxygen loss were calculated to be 1.67 and 2.12 eV on the RuO2 and Ni-RuO2 (110) surfaces, respectively, clearly demonstrating that the introduction of Ni dopants to the RuO2 lattice had also stabilized lattice oxygen during OER. Therefore, DFT studies indicated that the incorporation of Ni improved the OER stability of RuO2 by inhibiting both surface Ru demetallation and lattice oxygen loss (Figs. 21(a)–(e) ). Doping with other uncommon metals, such as Re, Nb, Nd, etc., has also been reported to improve the activity and stability of RuO2 [168–170]. Jin et al. [168] reported that the addition of Re dopants enables Ru sites to receive electrons at onsite potentials and donate them back at large overpotentials, as observed through operando XAS. This mechanism effectively prevents the dissolution of Ru. The introduction of Re doping reduces the adsorption energy of oxygen intermediates and strengthens the Ru–O bond in AEM pathway. Remarkably, Re0.06Ru0.94O2 exhibited an overpotential of 190 mV at current density 10 mA cm−2 during continuous 200 h test in 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4 with a S-number of 4.0 × 106. Liu et al. [169], on the other hand, found that the Ru sites in Nb-RuO2 provides electrons from Nb to Ru via bridging oxygen, thereby increasing electron density. In the OER process, the presence of Nb5+ in RuO2 inhibits the dissolution of Ru, strengthens the M–O bond in RuO2, and prevents the formation of soluble high-valent Ru substances. The designed Nb-Ru binary oxide shows a minimal overpotential (204 mV at 10 mA cm−2), a low degradation rate (25 μV h−1) over a 360-h stability test at 200 mA cm−2. Doping Ru-based catalysts with other metals is an efficient approach to modulate their electronic structures, thereby improving the activity and stability of catalysts for OER. Generally, the introduction of a quantitative amount of other metal salts during ruthenium catalyst synthesis can realize chemical doping. However, the dissolution of doped metal ions can be detrimental to the long-term stability of the catalyst. 4.5 Formation of solid solution The solid solution of pyrochlores and perovskites with special crystal structure have been proved active and stable for OER in water electrolysis. Pyrochlore is a complex oxide represented by a general formula of A2B2O7–y , where A site typically consists of Pb, Bi, Tl, Y, or Ln (rare-earth metal); and B site can be Ru [171–174]. Feng et al. [171] reported that the addition of Zn2+ doping into A site enhances the activity and stability of Y2Ru2O7–δ . The catalyst showed an overpotential of 291 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 and maintained its performance during a 6-h continuous testing without obvious decay. The intrinsic stability of Y2Ru2O7–δ is not affected by the partial substitutes of Zn for Y at A sites, which can be ascribed to the rigid RuO6 structure. The substitution of partial Y3+ with Sr2+ has also been reported to enhance the performance of Y2Ru2O7–δ [172]. The optimized Y1.7Sr0.3Ru2O7 candidate showed an overpotential of 161 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and demonstrated good stability for up to 28 h without any perceptible activity decline. The amount of dissolved metal detected was as low as 0.12% relative to the total catalyst. This excellent stability can be attributed to a good surface stability without structural reconstruction and/or metal dissolution during the OER process in acidic media. The enlargement of Ru–O–Ru bond angle, the alleviation of RuO6 octahedral distortion and the enhancement of Ru–O covalency are the main reasons for the stability of the crystal structure. The ligand oxygen is chemically activated to facilitate the nucleophilic OH− attack during OOH* formation, thus alleviating the energy barrier to further reduce η OER (Figs. 22(a)–(f) ). Yan et al. [173] introduced Ho3+ ions as substitutes for A-site atoms in Y2Ru2O7, resulting in an increased Ru–O–Ru bond angle and reduced the Ru–O bond length due to higher electronegativity with 4f electron effect. This substitute effectively mitigated the RuO6 octahedral distortion in Ho2Ru2O7. Moreover, Ho3+ improved the formation energy of oxygen vacancies, enhancing the resistance against Ru dissolution. Therefore, Ho2Ru2O7 displayed an overpotential of 215 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a long-term (> 60 h) stability in acidic media. A study conducted by Guo et al. [174] reported the synthesis of Y2–x Co x Ru2O7–δ pyrochlore, where partial yttrium was substituted with Co. This substitution exhibited an overpotential of 275 mV in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. After 2000 cycles, only a marginal decay of 3.6% in the catalytic activity was observed. The incorporation of Co through substitution strengthens of the bond hybridization between the d orbitals of metal (Y and Ru) and the 2p orbitals of O, thereby enhancing the chemical stability of the crystal. In addition to the doping of A site, the B site can also be partially replaced [175–177]. A series of Pb-substituted lead-ruthenate pyrochlore (Pb2[Ru2–x Pb x ]O7–δ , PRPO) were synthesized [175] by utilizing a low-temperature pyrolysis cation exchange resin method. The optimized catalyst exhibited an overpotential of 174 mV and sustained for 150 h to achieve 10 mA cm−2 at around 1.50 V with a slight voltage increase of 63 mV. According to the DFT results, the Ru–O average binding length of PRPO was 1.969 Å, which is shorter than that of RuO2 (1.992 Å). Therefore, its superior stability can be attributed to the more stable octahedral structure after doping Pb in B-site. It was also reported that doping Ir in B-site of yttrium ruthenate pyrochlore can also work [176]. The optimized Y2Ru2–x Ir x O7 catalyst gave a low overpotential of 220 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and maintained its performance over 2000 h. DFT calculations implied enhanced activity for both Ru and Ir sites in Ir-doped pyrochlore ruthenate. Derived from their calculated energy barriers, the Ir site exhibited a higher OER favorability in comparison with the Ru site. The high stability was attributed to the depressed overoxidation of the active species due to the low valence state and the high structural stability with strengthened interaction between RuO6 and IrO6 (Figs. 23(a)–(f) ). Overall, the balanced binding ability with oxygen intermediates, downshift of O 2p band center, and accelerated potential-determining steps collectively contributed to the enhanced activity and stability of Y2Ru2–x Ir x O7. Another study reported by Galyamin et al. [177] demonstrated that half of the Ru content can also be replaced by Mn to form low-Ru-content pyrochlores (Y2MnRuO7). In this case, an overpotential of 260 mV was required to achieve 10 mA cm−2 and the catalyst remained stable for 45 h during CP measurement. The substitution of Mn for Ru is responsible for maintaining the structural stability of the catalyst. Only a few examples of perovskites with high OER activity were reported in acid media [178–180]. The OER activity and durability of perovskite SrRuO3 in acid can be enhanced by Na+ doping in the Sr2+ position, as reported by Retuerto et al. [178]. Sr0.95Na0.05RuO3 exhibited very high specific OER activity, with an overpotential of ~160 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Na-doped perovskites experienced a modest decline of 15% from their initial activity after 20 cycles, while SrRuO3 encountered a substantial decrease exceeding 85%. The enhanced stability of Na-doped perovskites was attributed to the robust perovskite structure with stabilization of Ru centers in the form of higher oxidation states and less distorted RuO6 octahedra. Miao et al. [179] reported a quadruple perovskite oxide CaCu3Ru4O12 as an efficient catalyst for acidic water oxidation, which exhibited an overpotential of 171 mV and a lifetime of 24 h at 10 mA cm−2. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) measurements revealed the dissolution percentage of Ca, Cu and Ru ions were less than 6.7%, 2.9% and 2.7%, respectively in acid conditions, which can be attributed to the excellent chemical and structural stability of this perovskite material. Liu et al. [180] investigated a series of quadruple perovskite ruthenates (ACu3Ru4O12, A = Ca, Sr, La, Nd, and Ce) to evaluate activities and stabilities during OER. Among all the samples tested, CaCu3Ru4O12 exhibited the highest activity and stability. The improved OER cycle stability can be attributed to the increased Ru-O covalency with decreased Ru–O bond length. The solid solutions of Ru-based catalysts with rutile phase have also been reported as active and stable catalysts for OER. It has been reported that the introduction of Cr into RuO2 to form chromium-ruthenium oxide solid solution enhances the acidic OER performance. Specifically, a low overpotential of 178 mV at 10 mA cm−2 was achieved for Cr0.6Ru0.4O2 and this level of performance was maintained at least for 10 h [181]. The enhanced stability was related to the stabilization of rutile crystalline structure due to lower occupation at the Fermi level. Moreover, various chromium-ruthenium oxide solid solution with different Cr/Ru ratios were also synthesized via sol-gel method. Among them, Ru0.6Cr0.4O2 delivered an overpotential of only 195 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The applied potential was merely increased by 5.3 mV for 20 h during a continuous OER test in acidic media. The incorporation of Cr increased the energy required for oxygen defect formation and reduced the participation of lattice oxygen, thus improving the stability of the catalyst [182]. Many investigators have focused on the construction of solid solutions with unique crystal structures, especially pyrochlore structures with RuO6 active centers. The catalyst possesses a singular crystal structure, facilitating catalytic mechanism modeling and analysis. However, the dissolution of metal within the crystal lattice can readily cause the structural collapse and surface reconstruction, which is not conducive to long-term stability. Therefore, it is significant to design catalysts with robust structures and high capability against metal dissolution under operation conditions. 4.6 Alternated reaction pathways As previously mentioned, the participation of activated lattice oxygen in the LOM is the main factor that leads to inadequate stability of Ru-based catalysts. This is because the generated oxygen vacancy (VO) defects cause the exposure of metal species and subsequent over-oxidation, resulting in the detachment from the catalyst surface. Therefore, one of the core strategies is to improve the stability of catalyst by changing the reaction mechanism of catalyst in order to suppress LOM process [183–188]. Hao et al. [183] modified the electronic structure of RuO2 via co-doping W and Er, resulting in a downward shift of the O 2p-band centers. This modification effectively increases the energy (ΔG) required for the VO formation, thereby preventing the participation of lattice oxygen and minimizing the generation of soluble high valence Ru>4+. The representative W0.2Er0.1Ru0.7O2–δ catalyst showed a low overpotential of 168 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 accompanied with a stability at least 500 h in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 electrolyte. The ICP-MS results revealed that the concentration of Ru cations in the solution was below12 ppb after 500 h, indicating that only a slight amount of Ru is dissolved and the stability is improved significantly (Figs. 24(a)–(h) ). Wen et al. [184], on the other hand, developed a ternary oxide electrocatalysts consisting of Sr-Ru-Ir, which achieved an overpotential of 190 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and maintained an overpotential below 225 mV during 1500 h of operation. On the basis of the ICP-OES data, the S-number for SrRuIr (1.97 × 104) is approximately 2 orders of magnitude higher than that for SrRu (4.10 × 102). Based on X-ray absorption spectroscopy and 18O isotope-labeled online mass spectroscopy studies, the interactions in the Ru–O–Ir local structure suppressed the participation of lattice oxygen during OER, attributing to the enhanced stability. To steer the AEM in OER for improved durability of the RuO2 phase in acidic electrolytes, Jin et al. [185] designed a nanorod-shaped PtCo-RuO2/C that showed 212.6 mV overpotential and a lifetime of 20 h at 10 mA cm−2. Pt dopants were found not only to promote *OOH adsorption and deprotonation, facilitating AEM, but also to sacrificially oxidize and dissolve instead of Ru in order to prevent Ru from over-oxidation. Wen et al. [186] presented a strategy to accelerate the deprotonation of OER intermediates by introducing WO x as strong Brönsted acid sites into the RuO2. The Ru-W binary oxide exhibited a low overpotential of 235 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a 550-hour stability test with a low degradation rate. This approach facilitated the transfer of proton from the oxo-intermediate to the neighboring bridging oxygen sites, thus accelerating bridging-oxygen-assisted deprotonation during OER steps. Shi et al. [187] have used MRuO x (M = Ce4+, Sn4+, Ru4+, Cr4+) solid solution as structure model, finding the relationship between the reaction route and the Ru charge. By varying the chelating elements surrounding the RuO6 motif and controlling the M-O-Ru structure, they were able to selectively involve or exclude the LOM and optimize both activity and stability under AEM pathway. SnRuO x solid solution with Sn-O-Ru local structure that follows the AEM with appropriate Ru–O binding strength. The screened out SnRuO x solid solution exhibited an overpotential of 194 mV at 10 mA cm−2 along with a sustained operation for a 250-h at 100 mA cm−2 (Figs. 25(a)–(g) ). In contrast to LOM, the oxide path mechanism (OPM) is more promising for designing high-performance OER electrocatalysts due to the direct O–O radical coupling avoiding from the production of oxygen vacancy defects and extra reaction intermediates [188]. However, the geometric configuration of metal active sites increases the difficulty of implementing OPM. An in-situ reconstructed Ru atom array on α-MnO2 has been reported by Lin et al. [188], which showed high activity with an overpotential of 161 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and outstanding stability with small degradation after 200 h operation with 1.32 wt% Ru loading. The mass loss ratios of Ru and Mn in the 12Ru/MnO2 catalyst were found out to be remarkably low at only 0.50% and 0.28%, respectively, after undergoing stable test over long periods. To validate the OPM pathway, a combination of operando vibrational and mass spectroscopy measurements along with DFT calculations were performed to probe the reaction intermediates and gaseous products (Figs. 26(a)–(f) ). Alternating the reaction pathway from LOM to AEM or OPM might provide solution to figure out the problem of the exposure and over-oxidation of Ru-based catalysts caused by oxygen vacancy formation in the LOM pathway. However, the discovery of the catalysts design principle capable of alternating the reaction pathway remains elusive, and there is still a relative lack of research focusing on enhancing stability under LOM pathways. In addition, despite numerous reports on Ru-based catalysts following the AEM pathways, their stability remains unsatisfactory, necessitating further stability improvement under this pathway. According to the recent advancements of the stability of Ru-based catalysts for OER, the strategies to improve the stability can be categorized into the following six types: hybridization of Ru-based catalysts with iridium, construction of core-shell structures, incorporation of stable support, chemical doping, formation of solid solution and alternated reaction pathways (Fig. 27 ). The timeline shows that every design idea is out of date. The deactivation mechanism of the Ru-based catalysts in OER is mainly the dissolution of ruthenium. Therefore, the design principle of catalysts is to enhance the stability of crystal structure and increase the dissolution resistance of ruthenium. In addition, to address the dissolution of ruthenium caused by LOM pathway, alternating the reaction pathway can be adopted. Introducing stable ingredients as secondary catalytic sites may provide a comprehensive solution to the stability issue. 5 Recent advances of Ru-based electrocatalysts for water-splitting The combination of HER and OER enables efficient and environmentally friendly electrocatalytic overall water splitting, which holds great promise for sustainable hydrogen production with high purity. The activity and stability of Ru-based catalysts in alkaline and acidic electrolytes for electrocatalytic water splitting are summarized in Table 3 . RuNP@RuN x -OFC/NC catalysts, in combination with anode IrO2, demonstrated a remarkable performance, achieving the current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a record-low cell voltage of 1.337 V in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH, while NC@Vo·-RuO2/CNTs-350 catalysts coupled with the commercial Pt/C as counter electrode catalysts required a higher potential of 1.45 V to drive the same current density (10 mA cm−2) for overall water splitting in the acidic media [104,152]. Several catalysts can be employed as bifunctional catalysts for both hydrogen and oxygen production. The electrocatalytic water splitting in the case of the a/c-RuO2||a/c-RuO2 system occurred at approximately 1.45 V and processed at 1.52 V for a current density of 10 mA cm−2. This system outperformed the Pt/C||RuO2 system [191]. Moreover, the a/c-RuO2||a/c-RuO2 system exhibited a remarkable catalytic stability in acidic media. A current retention of 68.5% was observed for the a/c-RuO2||a/c-RuO2 system during a period of 20 h at a current density of 50 mA cm−2, which was much higher than that of the Pt/C||RuO2 system (34.2%, Figs. 28(a)–(c) ). RuO2-NiO/NF, as a self-supporting electrode, served as both the anode and cathode for the basic overall water splitting (1.0 mol L−1 KOH) in a two-electrode configuration. RuO2-NiO/NF||RuO2-NiO/NF electrolyzer could generate a remarkable current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low cell voltage of 1.43 V, which was significantly lower than those of Pt/C||RuO2 (1.52 V) and RuO2||RuO2 (1.55 V) [97]. Moreover, RuO2-NiO/NF||RuO2-NiO/NF only required a voltage of about 1.66 V to reach 500 mA cm−2 with a faradaic efficiency of close to 100%. The RuO2-NiO/NF||RuO2-NiO/NF electrolyzer can maintain stable electrolysis performance with a duration up to 2000 h measured at both 100 mA cm−2 and 1000 mA cm−2. ICP-OES analysis suggests the minimal dissolution of Ru and Ni in the electrolyte, suggesting the potential for practical industrial application (Figs. 28(d)–(f)). To further evaluate the performance of these prepared electrocatalyst in the practical applications, cell tests were conducted using proton and anion exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWE and AEMWE). Generally, the cells consist of aluminum end plates, silicon gaskets, current collectors, membrane electrode assembly (MEA), and gas diffusion layers (GDL, Fig. 28(g)). To verify the practical application of Ru-WO3 catalysts in water electrolyzer, a AEMWE electrolyzer was assembled with the commercial IrO2 as anode and Ru-WO3-20% as cathode. The assembled electrolzyer required 1.86 V to achieve a current density of 1 A cm−2 at 80 °C [128]. The electrolyzer delivered a high stability without any obvious degradation at 1 A cm−2 for 100 h, indicating its promising potential for electrocatalytic water splitting. Due to the more irreplaceable performance in acidic electrolytes, many Ru-based catalysts have been employed in PEMWE. The Ni-RuO2/PEM/Pt/C electrolyzer required only 1.78, 1.95 and 2.10 V to reach the catalytic current densities of 500, 1000 and 1500 mA cm−2 at room temperature, respectively [167]. To assess the stability of the Ni-RuO2-based electrolyzer, as well as pristine RuO2 for comparison, a constant current density of 200 mA cm−2 was applied for evaluation purposes. The voltage of the RuO2 electrolyzer noticeably increased after approximately 120 h of continuous electrolysis, suggesting poor OER stability under practical operation conditions. In contrast, the Ni-RuO2 catalyst was operated for 1000 h without any obvious cell voltage increase, indicating the markedly PEMWE durability. A rapid increase of Ru concentration in electrolyte was observed at the initial stage of operation, which could be ascribed to the dissolution of unstable Ru species during the catalyst activation. Afterward, Ru dissolution was gradually stabilized at approximately 3 × 10−8 within the first 500 and remained nearly unchanged for the subsequent stability test. The optimal SnRuO x catalysts were also assessed in a single cell to evaluate their performance in a PEMWE device. The cell voltages of 1.565, 1.655, and 1.735 V were required to reach current densities of 1, 2, and 3 A cm−2 at 50 °C, respectively; these values were significantly higher than those obtained by the commercial RuO2 (1.733 V@1 A cm−2 and 1.883 V@2 A cm−2) [186]. The SnRuO x -based cell delivered a low apparent degradation rate of 53 μV h−1 under 1 A cm−2 for 1300 h, demonstrating the well-maintained PEMWE performance. SrRuIr catalysts displayed exceptional activity in a PEMWE device with the overall cell voltage of 1.50 V at 1 A cm−2 at 80 °C [184]. Upon applying a constant current of 1 A cm−2, no significant increase in cell voltage was observed after 150 h of electrolysis (Figs. 28(h) and (i)). 6 Conclusion and perspectives This review provides a comprehensive summary of the mechanism, evaluation methods, criteria of stability as well as deactivation for HER and OER. Additionally, it highlights the latest advancements and strategies of Ru-based HER and OER electrocatalysts with the improved catalytic stability. The deep understandings on targeted solutions to address the deactivation mechanisms in HER and OER were outlined, providing a clear pathway for improving the stability of Ru-based electrocatalysts in future research. Particularly, the strategies for enhancing HER performance of Ru-based electrocatalysts are elucidated from the following aspects: incorporation of conductive substrate, construction of core-shell structures, formation of embedded structures, enhancement of the metal-support interaction, phase engineering, and modulations of adsorption and desorption behavior of intermediates. Afterwards, emphasis is placed on the progress and strategies for enhancing the stability of Ru-based electrocatalysts for OER. This progress can be categorized into the following aspects hybridizing Ru-based catalysts with iridium, constructing core-shell structures, introducing stable supports, doping with specific element, forming solid solution, and alternating reaction pathways (Fig. 29 ). Despite gratifying progress has been made in the field of HER and OER, there remain considerable obstacles in developing Ru-based catalysts for practical water-splitting applications that exhibit both high activity and stability. We put forward prospects for the future development of Ru-based electrocatalysts for HER and OER (Fig. 30 ). 6.1 Development of the stability testing strategy and evaluation criteria The ultimate practicality of catalysts is determined by their stability which can be evaluated through stability testing methods under practical conditions for HER, such as exposure to high temperatures and strong bases/acids. However, only a limited number of catalysts have demonstrated the ability to withstand such harsh testing environments. Therefore, there is an urgent need for development of catalysts that can maintain stability in more challenging environments. The current laboratory stability testing method has been tried to simulate and predict the performance of the catalyst in real water electrolyzer. However, it raises concerns about whether this approach can really guarantee the long-term functionality of device for years, since there is no clear way to assess the stability of the catalyst in the actual application. In practice, the electrolytic cell experiences operational intermittency with frequent startups and static conditions, whether such operations affect the stability of the catalyst remains unclear. To reflect this phenomenon, a novel stability test method needs to be developed. Furthermore, establishing more reasonable criteria for quantifying and comparing the stability of different OER catalysts are essential for fair evaluation purposes. 6.2 Understanding of deactivation mechanism The understanding of deactivation mechanism influences the explanation and design principles of the stable catalysts. The primary deactivation modes of catalyst in HER involve support corrosion, metal atom dissolution, Osterwald ripening, agglomeration, particle detachment and active site poisoning. However, the underlying factors for these deactivation phenomena remain inadequately comprehended, taking the dissolution mechanism of metal atoms in an alkaline system as an example. In addition to OH* poisoning the active site, other species may also act as potential poisons. The formation of ruthenium with high valence resulting in dissolution is a well-known cause of deactivation in OER. Some researchers believe that the deactivation occurs due to the formation of oxygen vacancies and structural collapse caused by lattice oxygen participating in the generation of oxygen. However, the clarity and acceptance of LOM are considerably lower compared to that of AEM. Therefore, AEM is reported to as the predominant reaction pathway for most catalysts. Under such mechanism, how does high-valent ruthenium dissolve, and whether there is a strategy to fundamentally solve this problem remains to be explored. 6.3 Development and application of in-situ technologies The structure of the active site in electrocatalysts is ambiguous and challenging to capture, due to the complex nature of the three-phase electrocatalytic reaction involving solid, liquid and gas phases, as well as multiple electron transfer and intermediates. It may also be accompanied by complex surface reconstruction and catalyst modifications in the electrocatalytic process. Therefore, it is imperative to employ in-situ characterization technologies for real-time monitoring of the dynamic catalytic process and capturing catalyst change, enabling a comprehensive understanding of the deactivation mechanisms. Advanced in-situ techniques, such as operando XAFS, in-situ XRD, TEM, Raman, etc. are essential for detecting the atomic level changes of valence state, structure, recombination, morphology, defect and other changes in real time. Only through a clearer understanding of the deactivation mechanisms can targeted solutions be proposed to improve the stability of the catalyst. 6.4 Utilization of advanced modification strategies Conventional modification strategies include composition regulation, structural modulation, heterojunction construction, and electron orbital regulation. Other methodologies, such as amorphous supports, Van der Waals heterojunction, spin state regulation, microenvironment regulation, etc., have shown potential in improving the performance of Ru-based catalysts for water splitting. Amorphization can generate abundant metal dangling bonds with the flexibly unsaturated electronic configurations to facilitate frequent couplings of orbitals, rearrange the distribution of the local lone-pair electrons and accelerate charge transfer among active centers. Amorphous supports that confine single atoms or diatoms can not only enhance activity but also improve stability. The paramagnetic product O2 from diamagnetic hydroxide/water requires spin-related electron transfer, which can be facilitated by the hybridization between the transition metal 3d and oxygen intermediate 2p orbitals. The formation of active sites (M) and oxygen intermediate (e.g., OH*, O*, OOH*) bonds (M–O) are a prerequisite of OER. Thus, regulating the spin state of active metal sites or supports can ensure rapid catalytic kinetic. Since the catalytic reaction is sensitive to the properties of the surface/interface, regulating the local interfacial microenvironment of active sites in heterogeneous catalysts induces charge redistribution, creates new active sites and enhances the catalytic performance. 6.5 Highly desired practical application Several other significant breakthroughs are urgently required to facilitate the practical application of these Ru-based electrocatalysts in industrial water electrolysis. Firstly, it is crucial to develop stable electrocatalysts through scalable and straightforward synthesis methods for large-scale production. It is urge to construct a production scale of free-standing and large-area electrode with catalysts in order to remove the unstable adhesive and avoid disintegrating over a long period of operation. Additionally, it is necessary to develop bifunctional electrocatalysts with high stability toward both OER and HER, simplifying the construction of an electrolyzer while reducing the manufacturing costs. Moreover, parameters such as local pH, mass transfer resistance, bubble evolution rate, etc. need to be considered for the electrolyzers operating at high current density. Lastly, in actual production environments, it is essential for the catalyst to be minimally affected by impurities in the electrolyte such as dust and microorganisms. References 1 M.S. Yuanyuan Ma (School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University) is a professor at the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University. She received her B.S. in Materials Science and Engineering from Nanjing University in 2001 and Ph.D from the University of California, Davis in 2012. Her current research focuses on the design of highly performed electrocatalysts for water splitting and organic transformations as well as the reaction mechanisms for electrochemical reactions. Yongquan Qu (School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University) is a professor at the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University. He received his B.S. in Materials Science and Engineering from Nanjing University in 2001, M.S. in Chemistry from the Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics in 2004, and Ph.D in Chemistry from the University of California, Davis, in 2009. He worked as a postdoctoral research fellow in the University of California, Los Angeles, from 2009 to 2011. His research interests focus on heterogeneous catalysis in the areas of organic synthesis, clean energy production and biomimetic catalysis.

coredata.dc:description: Clean and renewable energy is generally localized and intermittent. Thus, energy conversion and storage technologies are necessary to compensate for these shortcomings. Electrolytic water splitting presents a reliable and promising energy technology for producing high purity hydrogen (H2). Among the platinum metals, ruthenium (Ru) has gained significant attentions as it generally outperforms commercial catalysts in terms of activity at a more affordable price. Although great progress has been made in improving the catalytic activity of Ru-based catalysts, stability remains a major challenge hindering their practical applications. To this end, this review introduces the fundamentals of the stability over Ru-based catalysts for water splitting, including the reaction mechanisms of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), measurement methods and evaluation criteria, as well as deactivation mechanisms. Moreover, the up-to-date advances of representative strategies for improving HER and OER stability of Ru-based catalysts are further discussed with respect to specific design principles and underlying mechanisms. Ultimately, insights into the challenges and opportunities for Ru-based electrocatalysts are provided to promote the development of next-generation Ru-based catalysts with exceptional stability. This review aims at guiding the design and synthesis of superior catalysts, generating increased interest among researchers, and stimulating further advanced research.
